causes: Rivalry over control of Manchuria and Korea between the Russian Empire and the Empire of Japan.
Japan’s desire to expand its influence in East Asia, particularly over Korea and southern Manchuria.
Russia’s expansionist policies and the desire to secure access to warm-water ports in the Pacific, such as Port Arthur.
events_leading_up_to_war: Japan and Russia clashed over territorial control in Manchuria and Korea, with Japan growing increasingly frustrated with Russia's encroachment into the region.
Negotiations to resolve the dispute failed, and Japan launched a surprise attack on the Russian naval base at Port Arthur on 8 February 1904, marking the start of the war.

result.territorial_changes: Russia ceded Port Arthur, the Liaodong Peninsula, and South Sakhalin to Japan. Japan also gained a sphere of influence over Korea.

Japan.siege_equipment: Effective artillery, naval blockade, and amphibious assault capabilities

major_battles.name: Battle of Tsushima
major_battles.description: A decisive naval battle in the Tsushima Strait, where the Imperial Japanese Navy decisively destroyed the Russian fleet, crippling Russia's naval power in the Far East.
major_battles.outcome: Japanese victory, eliminating Russia’s naval presence in the Pacific and solidifying Japan’s dominance in the region.

major_battles.name: Battle of Mukden
major_battles.description: A major land battle between Russian and Japanese forces in Manchuria. The Japanese Army decisively defeated the Russian forces, marking the turning point of the war.
major_battles.outcome: Japanese victory, leading to the Russian retreat from Manchuria.

texts.name: Treaty of Portsmouth
texts.details: The Treaty of Portsmouth formally ended the Russo-Japanese War and outlined territorial changes and spheres of influence.

texts.name: Russian Imperial Navy Reports
texts.details: These reports document the preparations for the war, including the failed naval strategies that led to the defeat of Russia's fleet.

archaeological_evidence.type: Artifacts from the Battle of Tsushima
archaeological_evidence.description: Artifacts such as Japanese naval shells, shipwreck remains, and Russian naval equipment have been found in the Tsushima Strait.
Medals and battle commendations given to Japanese officers who participated in major battles such as Mukden and Tsushima.

historical_texts.name: The Russo-Japanese War: A New Kind of War
historical_texts.details: This work explores the technological advances and strategic shifts that characterized the Russo-Japanese War, especially the influence of modern warfare on the outcome.

historical_texts.name: Reports from the Russian General Staff
historical_texts.details: Official Russian reports from the General Staff documenting the failed Russian strategies and the impact of the defeat on Russian policy.

political: Russia’s defeat in the war led to domestic unrest, culminating in the Russian Revolution of 1905.
Japan emerged as a major world power and solidified its control over Korea and Manchuria, gaining recognition as a global military power.
long_term_effects: The war signified the emergence of Japan as the first non-Western power to defeat a European power in the modern era.
The war destabilized the Russian Empire, contributing to the events that eventually led to the Russian Revolution in 1917.

military: The war marked the first time in the modern era that an Asian power defeated a European power in a major conflict, changing the balance of power in the East.
The Battle of Tsushima is considered one of the most decisive naval battles in history and set the stage for modern naval warfare strategies.
political: The Russo-Japanese War marked Japan’s rise as a global military power, while highlighting the weakening position of the Russian Empire.
The war led to significant changes in the geopolitical landscape of East Asia, with Japan securing influence over Korea and parts of China.
cultural: The war had a profound impact on national pride and identity in Japan, reinforcing the image of Japan as a modern, militarily advanced nation.
In Russia, the defeat sparked social unrest, leading to the 1905 Revolution and the eventual transformation of Russia’s political system.
